title: Fitch Assigns Chengdu Jiaozi Financial Holding Group First-Time 'BBB+' Rating; Rates USD Bonds
text:
Fitch Assigns Chengdu Jiaozi Financial Holding Group First-Time 'BBB+' Rating; Rates USD Bonds

(The following statement was released by the rating agency) Fitch Ratings-Hong Kong/Shanghai-October 27: Fitch Ratings has assigned China-based Chengdu Jiaozi Financial Holding Group Co.,Ltd (CJFH) Long-Term Foreign- and Local-Currency Issuer Default Ratings (IDR) of 'BBB+'. The Outlook is Stable. Fitch has concurrently assigned CJFH's proposed US dollar senior unsecured bonds a 'BBB+(EXP)' expected rating. CJFH was established as a state-owned limited-liability company in 2008 and is ultimately fully owned by the State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission (SASAC) of Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan province. CJFH serves as Chengdu's state-owned investment-holding platform to consolidate the municipality's financial assets. The company is the largest shareholder of Bank of Chengdu and Jintai Insurance, and the second-largest shareholder of Chengdu Rural Commercial Bank. It also established the second licensed local asset-management company in the province. The proposed bonds will be issued by CJFH directly and rank pari passu with all its other present and future unsecured and unsubordinated obligations. The proceeds will be used for onshore project financing, refinancing and general corporate purposes. The final rating on the proposed bonds is contingent on the receipt of final documents conforming to information already reviewed. Key Rating Drivers 'Very Strong' Status, Ownership and Control: CJFH is ultimately 100% owned by the Chengdu SASAC on behalf of the municipal government. Under its current legal status, the government supervises, audits and monitors the company's operational and financial performance. Any major decisions such as the appointment of senior management and board members, strategy formulation, change in shareholding structure, financing plans and major investment projects will require approval from the government. 'Strong' Support Track Record and Expectations: CJFH has been provided with substantial government support, including capital injections, tax rebates, debt swaps and asset injections. CJFH received CNY3.4 billion in capital injections, CNY1.1 billion in tax rebates, CNY0.4 billion in debt swaps and CNY0.5 billion from newly issued local government special bonds for infrastructure development during 2013-2018, while the government injected assets worth CNY10 billion in 2017. Fitch expects CJFH to continue to receive strong government support due to its important role in building Chengdu into the financial centre of western China. 'Moderate' Socio-Political Implications of Default: CJFH's key mission is to consolidate financial assets on behalf of the municipality and play a strategically important role to build Chengdu into China's financial centre in the western region. CJFH is also responsible for providing armed-escort services for local financial institutions. In the case of a default, Fitch believes the government is likely to use policy and fiscal measures to ensure the continued operation of its key subsidiaries, and to contain the adverse impact on the region's financial system. 'Very Strong' Financial Implications of Default: CJFH owns and controls a wide range of important financial-service providers as Chengdu's investment-holding platform to consolidate municipal financial assets and is well supported by China's large state-owned banks. Any potential default by CJFH could damage the reputation of the municipal government, and affect the availability of domestic or foreign financing options for other government-related entities (GRE) in Chengdu. 'b' Standalone Credit Profile: CJFH's Standalone Credit Profile is assessed under Fitch's Public Sector, Revenue-Supported Entities Rating Criteria, based on 'Weaker' revenue defensibility, 'Midrange' operating risk, and 'Weaker' financial profile due to high leverage, measured by net debt/Fitch-calculated EBITDA, of 18.4x at end-2018. Fitch believes CJFH is likely to maintain a similar profile in the medium term due to continued debt-funded capex, although ongoing financial support by the government will help mitigate its weak credit metrics. Derivation Summary Fitch assesses CJFH under our GRE rating criteria, reflecting the municipality's full ownership, direct control, strong support track record, and the strategic importance of CJFH to the local government. These factors indicate a strong incentive by the government to provide extraordinary support to CJFH, if needed.

CJFH's IDR was derived from the four factors under Fitch's GRE rating criteria and the 'b' Standalone Credit Profile under our Public Sector, Revenue-Supported Entities Rating Criteria. RATING SENSITIVITIES A change in Fitch's internal assessment of Chengdu municipality would lead to a revision in the company's ratings. An increase in the incentive for the municipality to provide support to CJFH, including stronger socio-political implications of default by the company, or a stronger support track record and expectations, may trigger positive rating action. The ratings may be downgraded if there is a significant weakening in the socio-political and financial implications of a default by CJFH, a weaker support track record and expectations from the government, or a dilution in the government's shareholding. Rating action on CJFH would lead to similar action on the proposed US dollar bonds. ESG Considerations Unless otherwise disclosed in this section, the highest level of ESG credit relevance is a score of 3 - ESG issues are credit neutral or have only a minimal credit impact on the entity, either due to their nature or the way in which they are being managed by the entity. For more information on our ESG Relevance Scores, visit www.fitchratings.com/esg.
